items.synopsis: In the 1967 referendum on Indigenous rights, the NSW electorate of Cowper recorded one of the highest "no" votes. Now, Gumbaynggirr elders are reflecting on past lessons as they prepare for the second Indigenous referendum in their lifetime.

title.children: 'Thorn in everybody's side': Elders share thoughts on the Voice vote

title.children: 'We didn't get rattled': Matildas strike back after Danish assault to reach World Cup quarters

image.altText: A side view of Roger Cook speaking at a press conference

items.synopsis: Just five weeks after being legislated, Roger Cook announces the WA government will be scrapping its Aboriginal Cultural Heritage Laws which he says caused 'division' and 'confusion' in the community.

title.children: 'Went too far': WA premier announces Juukan Gorge law repeal, denies Voice pressure from PM

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The WA Opposition had called for the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs Tony Buti to be sacked, as he was the minister responsible for the implementation of the laws. But when asked if Dr Buti would be sacked, Mr Cook was defiant. “No, and we won’t be listening to the Opposition on these sort of shrill political calls,” he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Minister won't be sacked

children.content: The WA Opposition had called for the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs Tony Buti to be sacked, as he was the minister responsible for the implementation of the laws.
But when asked if Dr Buti would be sacked, Mr Cook was defiant.
“No, and we won’t be listening to the Opposition on these sort of shrill political calls,” he said.

props.alt: A man standing in front of a flag

children.content: Tony Buti is the Minister responsible for the laws.
(ABC News: James Carmody)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: When asked if the public could feel confident in other legislation drafted under the Labor government, Mr Cook described these laws as "particularly complex". "Governments have been trying to strike a new set of laws around Aboriginal cultural heritage for decades," he said. "I know that because I've been involved in discussions with previous governments around these issues when I worked for Aboriginal land councils back in the early 2000s." "They are difficult laws to strike that balance. We haven't succeeded in this particular case. "I'm sorry about that, I'm sorry on behalf of the government."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'I'm sorry': Premier

children.content: When asked if the public could feel confident in other legislation drafted under the Labor government, Mr Cook described these laws as "particularly complex".
"Governments have been trying to strike a new set of laws around Aboriginal cultural heritage for decades," he said.
"I know that because I've been involved in discussions with previous governments around these issues when I worked for Aboriginal land councils back in the early 2000s."

props.alt: A close up of a man in front of a podium

children.content: Roger Cook says he's sorry about the outcome of the laws.
(ABC News: James Carmody)
"They are difficult laws to strike that balance. We haven't succeeded in this particular case.
"I'm sorry about that, I'm sorry on behalf of the government."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Mr Cook denied there had been any pressure exerted by the federal government to repeal the laws, amid speculation that confusion surrounding the act was muddying the waters around the Voice referendum. “I want to make this very clear, I have not had any communication with the prime minister’s office or any federal members in relation to these laws,” he said. Mr Cook did say he contacted the prime minister yesterday to brief him of the decision to repeal the laws.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: No pressure from Albanese, says WA Premier

children.content: Mr Cook denied there had been any pressure exerted by the federal government to repeal the laws, amid speculation that confusion surrounding the act was muddying the waters around the Voice referendum.
“I want to make this very clear, I have not had any communication with the prime minister’s office or any federal members in relation to these laws,” he said.
Mr Cook did say he contacted the prime minister yesterday to brief him of the decision to repeal the laws.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The West Australian government has announced it will overturn new Aboriginal cultural heritage laws, which were passed in 2021 after the destruction of sacred caves at Juukan Gorge in the Pilbara. The government will restore the original act from 1972 with "targeted, simple amendments" after an outcry from property owners over the new legislation. Under the new planned amendments, traditional owners will be able to appeal against development decisions under Section 18 of the 1972 act. Traditional owners were prohibited from appealing or talking publicly about Rio Tinto's plans to blow up the 46,000- year-old caves in 2020 under the old legislation. WA Premier Roger Cook says the new laws were too complicated and placed unnecessary burdens on property owners. "Today's announcement is about listening to the people of WA. "It' s about carefully considering the circumstances in front of us. "The Juukan Gorge tragedy was a global embarrassment for Australia, something needed to be done. "No-one can argue with that. "But our legislative response was wrong." Mr Cook rejected speculation that the WA government is repealing the laws to help the get the referendum on the Indigenous Voice to Parliament passed. "I have not had any communication with the prime minister or any federal members in relation to these laws." "The only contact I have had with the federal government in relation to these laws is when I contacted the prime minister yesterday to announce that we would be going in this direction." The Juukan Gorge traditional owners, the Puutu Kunti Kurrama and Pinikura Aboriginal Corporation, say they feel betrayed by the plans to repeal the new legislation. PKKP corporation chairman Terry Drage: “The previous heritage act, which predates Native Title, permitted the wanton destruction of  Juukan Gorge," he says. "While the new act is not perfect, it is better than what it replaced." “If the state government had listened to community feedback during the consultation phase, we  would not be in this mess." The PKKP has called on the federal government to proceed with national cultural heritage laws, as recommended by the parliamentary inquiry into the destruction of the Juukan Gorge caves. Mr Cook has ruled out "revisiting" new cultural heritage laws. Here's more from my colleague Keane Bourke in Perth.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: WA to repeal 2021 Aboriginal heritage laws

featuredLink.title: Live moment: 'The laws went too far': WA Premier announces repeal of controversial Aboriginal Cultural Heritage laws

children.content: The West Australian government has announced it will overturn new Aboriginal cultural heritage laws, which were passed in 2021 after the destruction of sacred caves at Juukan Gorge in the Pilbara.
The government will restore the original act from 1972 with "targeted, simple amendments" after an outcry from property owners over the new legislation.
Under the new planned amendments, traditional owners will be able to appeal against development decisions under Section 18 of the 1972 act.
Traditional owners were prohibited from appealing or talking publicly about Rio Tinto's plans to blow up the 46,000- year-old caves in 2020 under the old legislation.
WA Premier Roger Cook
says the new laws were too complicated and placed unnecessary burdens on property owners.
"Today's announcement is about listening to the people of WA.
"It' s about carefully considering the circumstances in front of us.
"The Juukan Gorge tragedy was a global embarrassment for Australia, something needed to be done.
"No-one can argue with that.
"But our legislative response was wrong."
Mr Cook rejected speculation that the WA government is repealing the laws to help the get the referendum on the Indigenous Voice to Parliament passed.
"I have not had any communication with the prime minister or any federal members in relation to these laws."
"The only contact I have had with the federal government in relation to these laws is when I contacted the prime minister yesterday to announce that we would be going in this direction."
The Juukan Gorge traditional owners, the Puutu Kunti Kurrama and Pinikura Aboriginal Corporation, say they feel betrayed by the plans to repeal the new legislation.
PKKP corporation chairman Terry Drage:
“The previous heritage act, which predates Native Title, permitted the wanton destruction of  Juukan Gorge," he says.
"While the new act is not perfect, it is better than what it replaced."
“If the state government had listened to community feedback during the consultation phase, we  would not be in this mess."
The PKKP has called on the federal government to proceed with national cultural heritage laws, as recommended by the parliamentary inquiry into the destruction of the Juukan Gorge caves.
Mr Cook has ruled out "revisiting" new cultural heritage laws.
Here's more from my colleague Keane Bourke in Perth.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This morning's gains on the ASX 200 index have eased back over lunchtime in directionless trade. The ASX 200 index is up by 0.1 per cent with slightly more sectors higher than lower. Education firms and miners have eked out gains, but there are small falls among real estate and industrial firms. Building materials maker James Hardie has surged (+14.4 per cent) on a strong outlook for the US housing market. However, it warned that housing markets "remain uncertain". While sales fell, James Hardie says net adjusted income rose 13 per cent for the first quarter of the 2024 financial year. Coking coal miner Coronado Global Resources (-12 per cent) saw half-year profit fall by 65 per cent to $US199 million ($304 million) because of lower coal prices. The Australian dollar has slipped 0.4 per cent to 65.44 US cents on the higher greenback.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX treads water

children.content: This morning's gains on the ASX 200 index have eased back over lunchtime in directionless trade.
The ASX 200 index is up by 0.1 per cent with slightly more sectors higher than lower.
Education firms and miners have eked out gains, but there are small falls among real estate and industrial firms.
Building materials maker
James Hardie
has surged (+14.4 per cent) on a strong outlook for the US housing market.
However, it warned that housing markets "remain uncertain".
While sales fell, James Hardie says net adjusted income rose 13 per cent for the first quarter of the 2024 financial year.
Coking coal miner
Coronado Global Resources
(-12 per cent) saw half-year profit fall by 65 per cent to $US199 million ($304 million) because of lower coal prices.
The Australian dollar has slipped 0.4 per cent to 65.44 US cents on the higher greenback.

props.alt: Table showing ASX 200 best and worst performers

children.content: ASX 200 top movers
(Refinitiv)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Myer shares (-13.7 per cent) have slumped after it forecast a weaker-than-expected profit for the 2023 financial year. The retailer predicts that after-tax profit will come in between $69 million and $73 million, up 15 to 21 per cent from a year ago, but below a forecast of $88.5 million by financial news service Refinitiv. Myer says sales rose 12.5 per cent from the 2022 financial year to $3.6 billion. That's despite deteriorating trading conditions over the first half of 2023. Australia is in the midst of a consumer recession as households cut back on spending because of high cost of living. Retail volumes have gone backward for three quarters in a row amid high interest rates and inflation. Myer chief executive John King: "We continue to tightly manage costs, inventory and cash to ensure we have a strong balance sheet as we begin FY24 where we expect the ongoing uncertainty around the macroeconomic environment to persist.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Retail woes hit Myer

children.content: Myer shares (-13.7 per cent) have slumped after it forecast a weaker-than-expected profit for the 2023 financial year.

The retailer predicts that after-tax profit will come in between $69 million and $73 million, up 15 to 21 per cent from a year ago, but below a forecast of $88.5 million by financial news service Refinitiv.
Myer says sales rose 12.5 per cent from the 2022 financial year to $3.6 billion. That's despite deteriorating trading conditions over the first half of 2023.
Australia is in the midst of a consumer recession as households cut back on spending because of high cost of living.
Retail volumes have gone backward for three quarters in a row amid high interest rates and inflation.
Myer chief executive John King:

"We continue to tightly manage costs, inventory and cash to ensure we have a strong balance sheet as we begin FY24 where we expect the ongoing uncertainty around the macroeconomic environment to persist.
